1.brief: to be clear (orig. of sound, but usually of color); to shine; hence, to make ashow, to boast; and thus to be (clamorously) foolish; to rave; causatively, to celebrate; also to stultify
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God

2.brief: probably to brighten up, i.e. (figuratively) be (causatively, make) blithe or gleesome
Jisrael, a symbolical name of Jacob; also (typically) of his posterity
to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
a son (as a builder of the family name), in the widest sense (of literal and figurative relationship, including grandson, subject, nation, quality or condition, etc., (like father or brother), etc.)
Tsijon (as a permanent capital), a mountain of Jerusalem
properly, to spin round (under the influence of any violent emotion), i.e. usually rejoice, or (as cringing) fear

3.brief: to be clear (orig. of sound, but usually of color); to shine; hence, to make ashow, to boast; and thus to be (clamorously) foolish; to rave; causatively, to celebrate; also to stultify
an appellation, as amark or memorial of individuality; by implication honor, authority, character
play upon it; to make music, accompanied by the voice; hence to celebrate in song and music

4.brief: (by implication) very widely used as a relative conjunction or adverb (as below); often largely modified by other particles annexed
to be pleased with; specifically, to satisfy adebt
Jehovah, Jewish national name of God
a people (as a congregated unit); specifically, a tribe (as those of Israel); hence (collectively) troops or attendants; figuratively, a flock
to gleam, i.e. (causatively) embellish; figuratively, to boast; also to explain (i.e. make clear) oneself; to shake a tree
depressed (figuratively), in mind (gentle) or circumstances (needy, especially saintly)
something saved, i.e. (abstractly) deliverance; hence, aid, victory, prosperity

5.brief: to jump for joy, i.e. exult
properly, weight, but only figuratively in a good sense, splendor or copiousness
properly, to creak (or emit a stridulous sound), i.e. to shout (usually for joy)
above, over, upon, or against (yet always in this last relation with a downward aspect) in a great variety of applications
a bed (figuratively, a bier); abstractly, sleep; by euphemism, carnal intercourse

6.brief: strength; as adjective, mighty; especially the Almighty (but used also of any deity)
drought; also a cutting instrument (from its destructive effect), as a knife, sword, or other sharp implement
a hand (the open one (indicating power, means, direction, etc.),

7.brief: to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application
avengement, whether the act of the passion
a foreign nation; hence, a Gentile; also (figuratively) a troop of animals, or a flight of locusts
chastisement; figuratively (by words) correction, refutation, proof (even in defence)
properly, a failure; by implication nothing; usually (adverb) not at all; also lest

8.brief: to yoke or hitch; by analogy, to fasten in any sense, to join battle
properly, what leaps forth, i.e. flash of fire, or a burning arrow; also (from the original sense of the root) a bond
to be heavy, i.e. in a bad sense (burdensome, severe, dull) or in a good sense (numerous, rich, honorable; causatively, to make weighty (in the same two senses)
iron (as cutting); by extension, an iron implement

9.brief: to do or make, in the broadest sense and widest application

properly, a verdict (favorable or unfavorable) pronounced judicially, especially a sentence or formal decree (human or (participant's) divine law, individual or collective), including the act, the place, the suit, the crime, and the penalty; abstractly, justice, including a participant's right or privilege (statutory or customary), or even a style
to grave, by implication, to write (describe, inscribe, prescribe, subscribe)

he (she or it); only expressed when emphatic or without a verb; also (intensively) self, or (especially with the article) the same; sometimes (as demonstrative) this or that; occasionally (instead of copula) as or are
properly, the whole; hence, all, any or every (in the singular only, but often in a plural sense)
to be clear (orig. of sound, but usually of color); to shine; hence, to make ashow, to boast; and thus to be (clamorously) foolish; to rave; causatively, to celebrate; also to stultify
